text: Hey! The simplest way to have multiple concurrent processes appending to a list would be having a lock guarding the list or does julia offer some other magic for this purpose?

elements.text: Hey! The simplest way to have multiple concurrent processes appending to a list would be having a lock guarding the list or does julia offer some other magic for this purpose?

text: Channels, I think. Haven't used em much

elements.text: Channels, I think. Haven't used em much

text: mmh, channels are overkill for my purposes I think

elements.text: mmh, channels are overkill for my purposes I think

text: and I heard they are not so good perf-wise

elements.text: and I heard they are not so good perf-wise

text: Locks are relatively slow, too, though I don't know if they are much slower than channels

elements.text: Locks are relatively slow, too, though I don't know if they are much slower than channels

text: (a Channel might just be a list with a lock, actually, not sure)

elements.text: (a Channel might just be a list with a lock, actually, not sure)

text: One thing I’ve done in the past is to have have a list of lists that is the same length as the number of processes, have each process append to its own list, and then concatenate afterwards to avoid locking overhead

elements.text: One thing I’ve done in the past is to have have a list of lists that is the same length as the number of processes, have each process append to its own list, and then concatenate afterwards to avoid locking overhead
